title: UBS traders drive Swiss bank's best first-quarter profits in 15 years
text:
UBS traders propelled the Swiss bank to its best first-quarter performance since 2007 as gains driven by volatile markets made up for a lacklustre performance by its wealth managers.

The world's largest wealth manager announced on Tuesday $2.7bn of profit before tax for the first quarter, up 19 per cent on last year and comfortably ahead of the $2.4bn predicted by analysts.

Profits at UBS's investment bank more than doubled compared with the first quarter last year, when it lost $774mn in the collapse of family office Archegos.

The bank benefited in the first quarter of 2022 from a 59 per cent increase in revenues in its trading division thanks to a strong performance in equity derivatives, interest rates and foreign exchange as the war in Ukraine caused market volatility.

But its wealth business was hit by a 7 per cent decline in revenues compared with the same period last year, with UBS saying transaction-based income fell 19 per cent as clients, particularly in Asia, drew back from markets.

“The first quarter was dominated by extraordinary geopolitical and macro events,” said Ralph Hamers, chief executive. “Against this backdrop, we remained focused on executing our strategic plans, serving our clients and managing risk.”

Analysts expected UBS to be the best-performing European investment bank in the first quarter, with the lender benefiting from higher revenues in its global markets division, which is focused on equities and foreign exchange.

Kian Abouhossein, an analyst at JPMorgan, said the slowdown in UBS's Asian wealth management business was expected, but this was outweighed by better than expected results in the investment bank.

“Overall the results are solid, capital not an issue and should lead to ongoing outperformance with limited concerns about Russia, credit risk and a resilient wealth management business,” he said.

In the days following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, UBS revealed it had $10mn in loans outstanding to clients targeted by western sanctions. It said it also had about $200mn of exposure to Russian assets used as collateral in Lombard lending and $634mn of direct risk exposure to the country.

On Tuesday, UBS said it had reduced its direct risk exposure to Russia by a third to about $400mn.

It added that EU and Swiss rules that prohibit accepting deposits of more than €100,000 from Russians not entitled to live in the European Economic Area affected 0.7 per cent of assets in its wealth management division.

The lender's share price is flat this year after recovering from a 28 per cent fall during the early days of the war in Ukraine.

UBS repurchased $1.7bn of shares in the first quarter as part of its $5bn buyback plan for the year.

The bank's shares were up 2.4 per cent in early trading on Tuesday.
